standard_metadata.standard_description: Convert among different-sized standard measurement units within a given measurement system (e.g., convert 5 cm to 0.05 m), and use these conversions in solving multi-step, real world problems.

question.content: Cory made $4{,}500 \text{ g}$ of candy.  He saved $1\text{ kg}$ to eat later.  He divided the rest of the candy over $7$ bowls to serve at his party.    **How  many *grams* of  candy did Cory serve in each bowl?**      $\text{g}$

hints.content: First, we need to convert the $1\text { kg}$ Cory saved to grams.    $1 \text{ kg}=\purpleD{1{,}000}\text{ g}$
Cory made $4{,}500 \text{ g}$ and saved $\purpleD{1{,}000}\text{ g}$.  We subtract to find out how much candy was left to serve at Cory's party.  $4{,}500-\purpleD{1{,}000}=\blueE{3{,}500}\text{ g}$

Cory has $\goldE{3{,}500}\text{ g}$ of candy to serve at the party.    He divides the $\goldE{3{,}500}\text{ g}$ evenly between $\maroonD7$ bowls.   [[☃ image 1]]    $\goldE{3{,}500}\div\maroonD7 = \tealE{500} \text{ g}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 3500. The bottom rectangle is divided into 7 equal parts, each labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 7 equal groups.

hints.content: Cory served $\tealE{500}\text{ g}$ in each bowl.

question.content: James has $14{,}500\text { g}$ of sand in his sandbox.  He brings home another $7{,}400\text { g}$ of sand from the beach to add to his sandbox.     **How  many *kilograms* of  sand does James have in his sandbox now?**     $\text{kg}$

hints.content: James had $14{,}500\text { g}$ and added  $7{,}400\text { g}$ more.     [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align}\goldE{14{,}500}\\ \underline{+~~\maroonD{7{,}400}}\\ \blueE{21{,}900}\end{align}$   James now has $\blueE{21{,}900}\text { g}$ of sand in his sandbox.

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total sand. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is shaded gold and is labeled 14,500. The second part is shaded maroon and is labeled 7,400. Across the blue part is a curved bracket labeled Sandbox sand. Across the maroon part is a curved bracket labeled Beach sand.

hints.content: We need to convert $\blueE{21{,}900}\text { g}$ to kilograms.    $1 \text{ g}=\dfrac1{1{,}000}\text{ kg}$  $\begin {align} &\quad{21{,}900} \text{ g}\\\\ &= {{21{,}900} \text{ g}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ kg}}{{1{,}000 \text{ g}}} \\\\ &= {\dfrac{21{,}900 \cancel{\text{ g}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ kg}}{{1{,}000 \cancel{\text{ g}}}} \\\\ &= \dfrac{{21{,}900 \text{ kg}}}{{1{,}000}} \\\\ &= {21{,}900 \text{ kg}}\div{1{,}000}\\\\ &={21.9\text{ kg}}\end{align}$
James has $21.9\text { kg}$ of sand in his sandbox.

question.content: Jemma filled one-fourth of a barrel with compost on Saturday.  Then she filled the remaining space with $4{,}200\text{ g}$ of compost on Sunday.    **How many *kilograms* of compost are in the barrel?**     kilograms

hints.content: After using up one fourth of the space in the barrel on Saturday, Jemma filled  the remaining $\dfrac{3}{4}$ on Sunday.     [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total barrel of compost. The bottom rectangle is divided into 4 equal parts. The first part is shaded maroon. The next 3 parts are shaded blue. A curved bracket across the pink part is labeled Saturday. A curved bracket across the blue parts is labeled 4,200 grams.

hints.content: We need to split $\blueE{4{,}200}$ grams into $3$ equal parts.    $\blueE{4{,}200}\div3=1{,}400\text{ g}$  So each fourth of the barrel contains $1{,}400\text{ g}$.    [[☃ image 1]]  How many grams are in the entire barrel?

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total barrel of compost. The bottom rectangle is divided into 4 equal parts, each labeled 1,400. The first part is shaded maroon. The next 3 parts are shaded blue. A curved bracket across the maroon part is labeled Saturday. A curved bracket across the blue parts is labeled 4,200 grams.

hints.content: The entire barrel contains $1{,}400 \times 4 = 5{,}600\text{ g}$.     [[☃ image 1]]  We need to convert $5{,}600\text{ g}$ to kilograms.

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 5,600. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total barrel of compost. The bottom rectangle is divided into 4 equal parts, each labeled 1,400. The first part is shaded maroon. The next 3 parts are shaded blue. A curved bracket across the maroon part is labeled Saturday. A curved bracket across the blue parts is labeled 4,200 grams.

hints.content: There are $5.6\text { kilograms}$ of compost in the barrel.

question.content: A Girl Scout camp served half of their granola with breakfast.  After dinner, they put the remaining $6{,}250 \text{ g}$ of granola on top of their yogurt dessert.      **How many *kilograms* of granola did the Girl Scout camp start with?**      kilograms

hints.content: Half of the granola is $6{,}250 \text { g}$.  So, we multiply by $2$ to find the total amount of granola.    [[☃ image 1]]  $6{,}250 \times 2 = 12{,}500 \text { g}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total granola. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 equal parts. The first part is labeled question mark. The second part is labeled 6,250. Across the first part is a curved bracket labeled Breakfast granola. Across the second part is a curved bracket labeled Yogurt granola.

hints.content: The Girl Scout camp started with $12{,}500 \text { g}$ of granola.   [[☃ image 1]]  We need to convert $12{,}500 \text { g}$ to kilograms.

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 12,500. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total granola. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 equal parts. The first part is labeled 6,250. The second part is labeled 6,250. Across the first part is a curved bracket labeled Breakfast granola. Across the second part is a curved bracket labeled Yogurt granola.

hints.content: The Girl Scout camp started with $12.5\text { kilograms}$ of granola.

question.content: Noah made $12 \text{ kg}$ of trail mix for his family's hiking trip.  His family ate $8{,}600 \text{ g}$ of the trail mix on the hiking trip.  **How  many *grams* of  trail mix did Noah have left?**     $\text{g}$

hints.content: First, we need to convert $12\text { kg}$ to grams.    $1 \text{ kg}=1{,}000\text{ g}$  So, $12 \text{ kg}=12\times1{,}000=12{,}000\text{ g}$.
We can subtract to see how much trail mix Noah has left.      [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align}\purpleD{12{,}000}\\ \underline{-~~\maroonD{8{,}600}}\\ \blueE{3{,}400}\end{align}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 12,000. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total trail mix. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is shaded maroon and is labeled 8,600. The second part is shaded blue and is labeled 3,400. Across the maroon part is a curved bracket labeled Trail mix eaten. Across the blue part is a curved bracket labeled Leftover.

hints.content: Noah had $3{,}400 \text{ g}$ of trail mix left.

question.content: Cora sliced $18 \text{ kg}$ of apples for a party.  She divided the apple slices equally between $5$ large bowls.   **How  many *grams* of  apple slices did Cora put in each bowl?**     $\text{g}$

hints.content: First, we need to convert $18\text { kg}$ to grams.    $1 \text{ kg}=1{,}000\text{ g}$  So, $18 \text{ kg}=18\times1{,}000=18{,}000\text{ g}$.
[[☃ image 1]]  Cora divided $\purpleD{18{,}000} \text{ g}$ into $\tealE5$ equal parts.   $\purpleD{18{,}000}\div \tealE5= \maroonD{3{,}600}\text{ g}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 18000. The bottom rectangle is divided into 5 equal parts, each labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 5 equal groups.

hints.content: Cora put $3{,}600 \text{ g}$ of apple slices in each bowl.

question.content: Kevin started his science test at  $2{:}34\text { p.m.}$ and finished the test $75$ minutes later. Kevin has football practice at $4{:}15 \text{ p.m.}$    **How much time did Kevin have between the end of the test and the beginning of football practice?**     minutes

hints.content: $\begin{align} 75\text{ mins} &= \tealE{60 \text{ mins}}+\purpleD{15 \text{ minutes}}\\\\ &= \tealE{1 \text{ hour}}+\purpleD{15 \text{ mins}}\\\\ &=\tealE{1 \text{ hour}}\text{ and } \purpleD{15 \text{ mins}} \end{align}$
[[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} &2{:}34 + \tealE{1\text{ hour}}=3{:}34\\\\ &3{:}34 +\purpleD{15\text{ minutes}}=3{:}49 \end{align}$  Kevin finished his test at $3{:}49\text{ p.m.}$

images.alt: A number line labeled from 2:30 to 4:00 with tick marks every 5 minutes. A line labeled plus 1 hour moves right from just before tick mark 2:35 to just before  tick mark 3:35. A line labeled plus 15 minutes moves right from just before tick mark 3:35 to just before tick mark 3:50.

hints.content: How much time did Kevin have between $3{:}49\text{ p.m.}$ and the beginning of football practice at $4{:}15\text{ p.m.}?$     [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 3:45 to 4:15 with tick marks every minute. A line labeled plus 11 minutes moves right from tick mark 3:49 to tick mark 4:00. A line labeled plus 15 minutes moves right from tick mark 4:00 to tick mark 4:15.

hints.content: $\blueE{11}\text{ mins} + \maroonD{15}\text{ mins} = 26\text{ mins}$
Kevin had ${26}$ minutes between the end of the test and the beginning of football practice.

question.content: Abigail's mom said she will be home from work in $65$ minutes. It is $4{:}27\text{ p.m.}$, and Abigail has dance practice at $6{:}00\text{ p.m.}$    **How much time will Abigail have between the time that her mom gets home from work and the beginning of dance practice?**     minutes

hints.content: $\begin{align} 65\text{ mins} &= \tealE{60 \text{ mins}}+\purpleD{5 \text{ minutes}}\\\\ &= \tealE{1 \text{ hour}}+\purpleD{5 \text{ mins}}\\\\ &=\tealE{1 \text{ hour}}\text{ and } \purpleD{5 \text{ mins}} \end{align}$
[[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} &4{:}27 + \tealE{1\text{ hour}}=5{:}27\\\\ &5{:}27 +\purpleD{5\text{ minutes}}=5{:}32 \end{align}$  Abigail's mom will be home at $5{:}32\text{ p.m.}$

images.alt: A number line labeled from 4:15 to 5:45 with tick marks every 5 minutes. A line labeled plus 1 hour moves right from just before tick mark 4:30 to just before tick mark 5:30. A line labeled plus 5 minutes moves right from just before tick mark 5:30 to just before tick mark 5:35.

hints.content: How much time will Abigail have between $5{:}32\text{ p.m.}$ and the beginning of dance practice at $6{:}00\text{ p.m.}?$    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 5:30 to 6:00 with tick marks every minute. A line labeled plus 13 minutes moves right from tick mark 5:32 to tick mark 5:45. A line labeled plus 15 minutes moves right from tick mark 5:45 to tick mark 6:00.

hints.content: $\blueE{13}\text{ mins} + \maroonD{15}\text{ mins} = 28\text{ mins}$
Abigail will have $28$ minutes between the time that her mom gets home from work and the beginning of dance practice.

question.content: Susan started her homework at  $1{:}59\text { p.m.}$ and finished her homework $96$ minutes later.  Susan had volleyball practice at $4{:}00\text{ p.m.}$   **How much time did Susan have between finishing her homework and the beginning of volleyball practice?**     minutes

hints.content: $\begin{align} 96\text{ mins} &= \tealE{60 \text{ mins}}+\purpleD{36 \text{ minutes}}\\\\ &= \tealE{1 \text{ hour}}+\purpleD{36 \text{ mins}}\\\\ &=\tealE{1 \text{ hour}}\text{ and } \purpleD{36 \text{ mins}} \end{align}$
[[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} &1{:}59 + \tealE{1\text{ hour}}=2{:}59\\\\ &2{:}59 +\purpleD{36\text{ minutes}}=3{:}35 \end{align}$  Susan finished her homework at $3{:}35\text{ p.m.}$

images.alt: A number line labeled from 1:45 to 3:45 with tick marks every 5 minutes. A line labeled plus 1 hour moves right from just before tick mark 2:00 to just before tick mark 3:00. A line labeled plus 36 minutes moves right from just before tick mark 3:00 to tick mark 3:35.

hints.content: How much time did Susan have between $3{:}35\text{ p.m.}$ and the beginning of volleyball practice at $4{:}00\text{ p.m.}?$   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 3:30 to 4:00 with tick marks every minute. A line labeled plus 10 minutes moves right from tick mark 3:35 to tick mark 3:45. A line labeled plus 15 minutes moves right from tick mark 3:45 to tick mark 4:00.

hints.content: $\blueE{10}\text{ mins} + \maroonD{15}\text{ mins} = 25\text{ mins}$
Susan had ${25}$ minutes between finishing her homework and the beginning of volleyball practice.

question.content: It is $4{:}12\text{ p.m.}$ Emma's mom will be home from work in $70$ minutes, and Emma has gymnastics lessons at $6{:}00\text{ p.m.}$   **How much time will Emma have between the time that her mom gets home from work and the beginning of gymnastics lessons?**     minutes

hints.content: $\begin{align} 70\text{ mins} &= \tealE{60 \text{ mins}}+\purpleD{10 \text{ minutes}}\\\\ &= \tealE{1 \text{ hour}}+\purpleD{10 \text{ mins}}\\\\ &=\tealE{1 \text{ hour}}\text{ and } \purpleD{10 \text{ mins}} \end{align}$
[[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} &4{:}12 + \tealE{1\text{ hour}}=5{:}12\\\\ &5{:}12 +\purpleD{10\text{ minutes}}=5{:}22 \end{align}$  Emma's mom will be home at $5{:}22\text{ p.m.}$

images.alt: A number line labeled from 4:00 to 5:30 with tick marks every 5 minutes. A line labeled plus 1 hour moves right from just before tick mark 4:15 to just before tick mark 5:15. A line labeled plus 10 minutes moves right from just before tick mark 5:15 to just before tick mark 5:25.

hints.content: How much time will Emma have between $5{:}22\text{ p.m.}$ and the beginning of gymnastics lessons at $6{:}00\text{ p.m.}?$   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 5:15 to 6:00 with tick marks every minute. A line labeled plus 8 minutes moves right from tick mark 5:22 to tick mark 5:30. A line labeled plus 30 minutes moves right from tick mark 5:30 to tick mark 6:00.

hints.content: $\blueE{8}\text{ mins} + \maroonD{30}\text{ mins} = 38\text{ mins}$
Emma will have ${38}$ minutes between the time that her mom gets home from work and the beginning of gymnastics lessons.

question.content: Payton leaves to go on an $85$ minute bike ride at $3{:}27\text{ p.m.}$  Payton's family eats dinner at $5{:}45\text{ p.m.}$   **How much time will Payton have between finishing her bike ride and eating dinner?**     minutes

hints.content: $\begin{align} 85\text{ mins} &= \tealE{60 \text{ mins}}+\purpleD{25 \text{ minutes}}\\\\ &= \tealE{1 \text{ hour}}+\purpleD{25 \text{ mins}}\\\\ &=\tealE{1 \text{ hour}}\text{ and } \purpleD{25 \text{ mins}} \end{align}$
[[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} &3{:}27 + \tealE{1\text{ hour}}=4{:}27\\\\ &4{:}27 +\purpleD{25\text{ minutes}}=4{:}52 \end{align}$  Payton finishes her bike ride at $4{:}52\text{ p.m.}$

images.alt: A number line labeled from 3:15 to 5:00 with tick marks every 5 minutes. A line labeled plus 1 hour moves right from just before tick mark 3:30 to just before tick mark 4:30. A line labeled plus 25 minutes moves right from just before tick mark 4:30 to just after tick mark 4:50.

hints.content: How much time will Payton have between $4{:}52\text{ p.m.}$ and dinner $5{:}45\text{ p.m.}?$   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 4:45 to 5:45 with tick marks every minute. A line labeled plus 8 minutes moves right from tick mark 4:52 to tick mark 5:00. A line labeled plus 45 minutes moves right from tick mark 5:00 to tick mark 5:45.

hints.content: $\blueE{8}\text{ mins} + \maroonD{45}\text{ mins} = 53\text{ mins}$
Payton will have ${53}$ minutes between finishing her bike ride and eating dinner.

question.content: Tony started his math project at  $1{:}57\text { p.m.}$ and finished the project $80$ minutes later. Tony has band practice at $4{:}00\text{ p.m.}$    **How much time did Tony have between the end of the project and the beginning of band practice?**     minutes

hints.content: $\begin{align} 80\text{ mins} &= \tealE{60 \text{ mins}}+\purpleD{20 \text{ minutes}}\\\\ &= \tealE{1 \text{ hour}}+\purpleD{20 \text{ mins}}\\\\ &=\tealE{1 \text{ hour}}\text{ and } \purpleD{20 \text{ mins}} \end{align}$
[[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align} &1{:}57 + \tealE{1\text{ hour}}=2{:}57\\\\ &2{:}57 +\purpleD{20\text{ minutes}}=3{:}17 \end{align}$  Tony finished his project at $3{:}17\text{ p.m.}$

images.alt: A number line labeled from 1:45 to 3:30 with tick marks every 5 minutes. A line labeled plus 1 hour moves right from just before tick mark 2:00 to just before tick mark 3:00. A line labeled plus 20 minutes moves right from just before tick mark 3:00 to just after tick mark 3:15.

hints.content: How much time did Tony have between  $3{:}17\text{ p.m.}$ and the beginning of band practice at $4{:}00\text{ p.m.}?$    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 3:15 to 4:00 with tick marks every minute. A line labeled plus 13 minutes moves right from tick mark 3:17 to tick mark 3:30. A line labeled plus 30 minutes moves right from tick mark 3:30 to tick mark 4:00.

hints.content: $\blueE{13}\text{ mins} + \maroonD{30}\text{ mins} = 43\text{ mins}$
Tony had ${43}$ minutes between finishing his math project and the beginning of band practice.

question.content: Gina mixed paint to make her favorite shade of purple. She filled one third of the container with red paint.  Then she filled the remaining space with $4\text{ L}$ of blue paint.    **How many *milliliters* of  paint did Gina mix?**     milliliters

hints.content: After using one third of the space in the container for red paint, Gina filled  the remaining $\dfrac{2}{3}$ with blue paint.      [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal lengths. The top rectangle is labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total paint. The bottom rectangle is divided into 3 equal parts. The first part is shaded maroon. The next 2 parts are shaded blue. Across the blue parts is a curved bracket labeled 4 liters.

hints.content: We can split $4$ liters into $2$ groups of $2\text{ L}$.  So each third of Gina's paint mix contains $2\text{ L}$ of paint.   [[☃ image 1]]   How many liters was the whole paint mix?

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal lengths. The top rectangle is labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total paint. The bottom rectangle is divided into 3 equal parts. The first part is shaded maroon. The next 2 parts are shaded blue and are each labeled 2 liters. Across the blue parts is a curved bracket labeled 4 liters.

hints.content: The whole paint mix was $2 \times 3 = 6\text{ L}$.     [[☃ image 1]]    We need to convert $6$ liters to milliliters.

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal lengths. The top rectangle is labeled 6 liters. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total paint. The bottom rectangle is divided into 3 equal parts. The first part is shaded maroon and labeled 2 liters. The next 2 parts are shaded blue and are each labeled 2 liters. Across the maroon part is a curved bracket labeled 2 liters. Across the blue parts is a curved bracket labeled 4 liters.

hints.content: Gina mixed $6{,}000$ milliliters of paint.

question.content: Coach Kelly brought $32 \text{ L}$ of water to the football game, and she divided the water equally between $8$ coolers.    **How  many *milliliters* of  water did Coach Kelly put in each cooler?**     $\text{mL}$

hints.content: Coach divided $32 \text{ L}$ into $8$ equal parts.   [[☃ image 1]]    $\purpleD{32\text{ L }} \div \tealE 8 = \maroonD{4 \text{ L}}$  Each cooler contained $\maroonD{4 \text{ L}}$ of water.

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 32. The bottom rectangle is divided into 8 equal parts, each labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 8 equal groups.

hints.content: Now, we need to convert $\maroonD{4\text{ L}}$ to milliliters.  $1 \text{ L} = 1{,}000\text{ mL}$.  So, $\maroonD{4\text{ L}}=4 \times {1{,}000} = 4{,}000 \text{ mL}$.
Coach Kelly put $4{,}000 \text{ mL}$ of water in each cooler.

question.content: Tony made $14 \text{ L}$ of lemonade for a party.  His guests drank $9{,}500 \text{ mL}$ of the lemonade.  **How  many *milliliters* of  lemonade did Tony have left over?**     $\text{mL}$

hints.content: First, we need to convert $14\text { L}$ to milliliters.    $1 \text{ L}=1{,}000\text{ mL}$  So, $14 \text{ L}=14\times 1{,}000=14{,}000\text{ mL}$.
Tony made $14{,}000\text{ mL}$ of lemonade, and his guests drank $9{,}500\text{ mL}$.      [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 14,000. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total lemonade. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is shaded pink and is labeled 9,500. The second part is shaded blue and is labeled question mark. Across the pink part is a curved bracket labeled Lemonade drank. Across the blue part is a curved bracket labeled Leftover.

hints.content: We can subtract to find out how much lemonade Tony had left over.    $\begin{align}14{,}000\\ \underline{-~~9{,}500}\\ 4{,}500\end{align}$    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 14,000. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total lemonade. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is shaded pink and is labeled 9,500. The second part is shaded blue and is labeled 4,500. Across the pink part is a curved bracket labeled Lemonade drank. Across the blue part is a curved bracket labeled Leftover.

hints.content: Tony had $4{,}500 \text { mL}$ of lemonade left over.

question.content: Wes mixed different juices to make fruit punch. He filled one-half of the punch bowl with orange juice.  Then he filled half of the remaining space with grape juice.  Finally, he filled the rest of the punch bowl with $300\text{ mL}$ of cherry juice.    **How many *liters* of fruit punch did Wes make?**      liters

hints.content: After filling half of the space in the container with orange juice, Wes filled half of the remaining space with grape juice and the other half with $\maroonD{300} \text { mL}$ of cherry juice.     [[☃ image 1]]  So, there is also $\purpleD{300} \text{ mL}$ of grape juice.

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total fruit punch. The bottom rectangle is divided into 3 unequal parts. The first part is shaded gold and is labeled question mark. The second part is shaded purple and is labeled 300. The third part is shaded maroon and is labeled 300. Across the orange part is a curved bracket labeled Orange. Across the purple part is a curved bracket labeled Grape. Across the maroon part is a curved bracket labeled Cherry.

hints.content: We need to add the amount of grape juice and cherry juice to determine the amount of orange juice.  $\maroonD{300} + \purpleD{300} = \goldE{600 \text{ mL}}$   [[☃ image 1]]  How many milliliters are in the whole fruit punch mix?

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total fruit punch. The bottom rectangle is divided into 3 unequal parts. The first part is shaded gold and is labeled 600. The second part is shaded purple and is labeled 300. The third part is shaded maroon and is labeled 300. Across the gold part is a curved bracket labeled Orange. Across the purple part is a curved bracket labeled Grape. Across the maroon part is a curved bracket labeled Cherry.

hints.content: The whole fruit punch mix was $\goldE{600} + \purpleD{300} + \maroonD{300}= \tealE{1{,}200\text{ mL}}$.     [[☃ image 1]]  We need to convert $1{,}200$ milliliters to liters.

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 1,200. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total fruit punch. The bottom rectangle is divided into 3 unequal parts. The first part is shaded orange and is labeled 600. The second part is shaded purple and is labeled 300. The third part is shaded pink and is labeled 300. Across the orange part is a curved bracket labeled Orange. Across the purple part is a curved bracket labeled Grape. Across the pink part is a curved bracket labeled Cherry.

hints.content: Wes mixed $1.2$ liters of fruit punch.

question.content: Molly made $3{,}600 \text{ mL}$ of tea for a party, and she served the tea divided equally in $12$ cups.    **How many *liters* of tea did Molly put in each cup?**     $\text{L}$

hints.content: Molly divided $3{,}600 \text{ mL}$ into $12$ equal parts.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{3{,}600 \text{ mL }} \div \tealE {12} = \maroonD{300 \text{ mL}}$  We need to convert $300 \text{ mL}$ to liters.

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 3600. The bottom rectangle is divided into 12 equal parts, each labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 12 equal groups.

hints.content: $1 \text{ mL}=\dfrac{1}{1{,}000}$ of a liter  $\begin {align} &\quad{300} \text{ mL}\\\\ &= {{300} \text{ mL}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ L}}{{1{,}000 \text{ mL}}} \\\\ &= {\dfrac{300 \cancel{\text{ mL}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ L}}{{1{,}000 \cancel{\text{ mL}}}} \\\\ &= \dfrac{{300 \text{ L}}}{{1{,}000}} \\\\ &= {300 \text{ L}}\div{1{,}000}\\\\ &={0.3\text{ L}}\end{align}$
Molly put $0.3\text{ L}$ of tea in each glass.

question.content: Thomas made $8{,}700 \text{ mL}$ of tomato soup.  He packed $1.6 \text{ L}$ of the soup in his kids' lunches.  He then froze half of the remaining soup.  **How  many *milliliters* of soup did Thomas freeze?**     $\text{mL}$

hints.content: First, we need to convert $1.6\text{ L}$ to milliliters.    $1 \text{ L}=1{,}000\text{ mL}$  So, $1.6 \text{ L}=1.6\times 1{,}000=1{,}600\text{ mL}$.

Thomas packed $1{,}600 \text { mL}$ of soup in his kids' lunches.     [[☃ image 1]]  We can subtract to find out how much he has left.   $\begin{align}\tealE{8{,}700}\\ \underline{-~~\goldE{1{,}600}}\\ 7{,}100\end{align}$  He has $7{,}100 \text{ mL}$ of soup after packing his kids' lunches.    He froze half of this amount.  What is half of $7{,}100 \text{ mL}?$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 8,700. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Tomato soup. The bottom rectangle is divided into 3 unequal parts. The first part is shaded gold and is labeled 1,600. The second part is shaded purple and is labeled question mark. The third part is shaded maroon and is labeled question mark. Across the gold part is a curved bracket labeled Kids’ lunch. Across the purple and maroon parts is a curved bracket labeled Left over.

hints.content: To find half of $7{,}100 \text{ mL}$, we divide by $2$.     [[☃ image 1]]  $7{,}100 \div2= 3{,}550 \text{ mL}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 8,700. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Tomato soup. The bottom rectangle is divided into 3 unequal parts. The first part is shaded gold and is labeled 1,600. The second part is shaded purple and is labeled 3,550. The third part is shaded maroon and is labeled 3,550. Across the gold part is a curved bracket labeled Kids’ lunch. Across the purple and maroon parts is a curved bracket labeled 7,100.

hints.content: Thomas froze $3{,}550 \text{ mL}$ of soup.

question.content: On Martin's first stroke, his golf ball traveled $\dfrac45$ of the distance to the hole.   On his second stroke, the ball traveled $79$ meters and went into the hole.    **How  many *kilometers* from the hole was Martin when he started?**     kilometers

hints.content: Martin's ball had to travel $\dfrac15$ of the total distance when he hit his second shot.      His second shot traveled $79 \text{ m}$.  So, $\dfrac15$ of the distance to the hole is $79 \text { m}$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Five blocks of equal size in a row. The first four blocks are striped and are labeled Stroke 1. The last block is solid and labeled Stroke 2 with the distance 79 meters within the block.

hints.content: We want to know what distance all $\dfrac55$ represent, so we multiply $79 \times 5$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Five blocks of equal size in a row. The first four blocks are labeled Stroke 1 and each block is labeled 79 meters. The last block is labeled Stroke 2 and 79 meters.

hints.content: $79 \times 5 = 395$    The total distance to the hole was $395$  meters.  $395 \text{ m} = \,? \text{ km}$

$1 \text{ m}=\dfrac{1}{1{,}000}\text { km}$  $\begin {align} &\quad{395} \text{ m}\\\\ &= {{395} \text{ m}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ km}}{{1{,}000 \text{ m}}} \\\\ &= {\dfrac{395 \cancel{\text{ m}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ km}}{{1{,}000 \cancel{\text{ m}}}} \\\\ &= \dfrac{{395 \text{ km}}}{{1{,}000}} \\\\ &= {395 \text{ km}}\div{1{,}000}\\\\ &={0.395\text{ km}}\end{align}$
Martin was $0.395$ kilometers from the hole when he started.

question.content: A bee flew $840 \text{ cm}$ and landed on a flower to collect some pollen.  Then the bee flew another $330 \text { cm}$ to get back to her hive.  **How  many *meters* did the bee travel?**     meters

hints.content: The bee traveled  $840 \text{ cm}$ to gather the pollen and  $330 \text{ cm}$ after.  We add to find her total distance.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\begin{align}\goldE{840}\\ \underline{+~~\purpleD{330}}\\ 1{,}170\end{align}$  The bee traveled $1{,}170 \text{ cm}$.

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total travelled. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is labeled 840. The second part is labeled 330. Across the first part is a curved bracket labeled Pollen. Across the second part is a curved bracket labeled Hive.

hints.content: We need to convert $1{,}170 \text{ cm}$ to meters.  $1 \text{ cm}=\dfrac{1}{100}\text { m}$  $\begin {align} &\quad{1{,}170} \text{ cm}\\\\ &= {{1{,}170} \text{ cm}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ m}}{{100 \text{ cm}}} \\\\ &= {\dfrac{1{,}170 \cancel{\text{ cm}}}{1}}\times \dfrac{1 \text{ m}}{{100 \cancel{\text{ cm}}}} \\\\ &= \dfrac{{1{,}170 \text{ m}}}{{100}} \\\\ &= {1{,}170 \text{ m}}\div{100}\\\\ &={11.7\text{ m}}\end{align}$
The bee traveled $11.7$ meters.

question.content: A carpenter had a board that was $5.28 \text { m}$ long.  She used her circular saw to cut $9 \text{ cm}$ off the end of the board.  **How  many *centimeters* long was the board after the carpenter cut it?**       centimeters

hints.content: First, we need to convert $5.28 \text{ m}$ to centimeters.  $1\text{ m} = 100 \text { cm}$   So, $5.28\text{ m} = 5.28 \times {100}=528\text{ cm}$.
The carpenter cut $9 \text{ cm}$ off the end of the board.   We subtract to find the new length of the board.  $\begin{align}528\\ \underline{- ~~~9}\\ 519\end{align}$
The board was $519 \text{ centimeters}$ long after the carpenter cut it.

question.content: Issa jogged two-thirds of the way home from school.  Then he was tired, so he walked the remaining $3{,}200\text{ m}$.  **How  many *kilometers* did Issa travel from school to his house?**     kilometers

hints.content: Issa had $\dfrac13$ more of the way to go when he started to walk.      Issa walked $\purpleD{3{,}200 \text{ m}}$.  So, $\dfrac13$ of the way to his house is $3{,}200 \text{ m}$.   [[☃ image 1]]  We want to know what distance all $\dfrac33$ represent, so we multiply $\purpleD{3{,}200} \times 3$.

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal lengths. The top rectangle is labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total distance. The bottom rectangle is divided into 3 equal parts. The first 2 parts are shaded gold. The next part is shaded purple and is labeled 3,200. Across the gold parts is a curved bracket labeled Jogged. Across the purple part is a curved bracket labeled Walked.

hints.content: $3{,}200 \times 3 = 9{,}600 \text{ m}$      [[☃ image 1]]  The total distance Issa traveled was $9{,}600$ meters.  $9{,}600 \text{ m} = \,? \text{ km}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal lengths. The top rectangle is labeled 9,600. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total distance. The bottom rectangle is divided into 3 equal parts, each labeled 3,200. The first 2 parts are shaded gold. The next part is shaded purple. Across the gold parts is a curved bracket labeled Jogged. Across the purple part is a curved bracket labeled Walked.

hints.content: Issa traveled $9.6$ kilometers from school to his house.

question.content: Lisa went on a $52 \text { km}$ hike.  She divided the distance traveled evenly over $4$ days.    **How  many *meters* did Lisa walk each day?**     meters

hints.content: Lisa divided $52 \text{ km}$ into $4$ equal parts.   [[☃ image 1]]    $\purpleD{52}\text{ km } \div \tealE 4 = \maroonD{13} \text{ km}$  Lisa walked $\maroonD{13} \text{ km}$ each day.

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 52. The bottom rectangle is divided into 4 equal parts, each labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 4 equal groups.

hints.content: We need to convert $13 \text{ km}$ to meters.  $1\text{ km} = 1{,}000 \text { m}$   So, $13\text{ km} = 13 \times {1{,}000}=13{,}000\text{ m}$.
Lisa walked $13{,}000 \text{ meters}$ each day.

question.content: The library is $14.2 \text { km}$ away from Daniel's apartment.  The bus takes Daniel $11.15 \text { km}$ of the way to the library.  He has to walk the remaining distance.    **How  many *meters* does Daniel have to walk?**     meters

hints.content: We subtract the distance the bus takes Daniel from the total distance to the library to find out how far Daniel has to walk.    $\begin{align}14.20\\ \underline{-~~11.15}\\ 3.05\end{align}$  Daniel walks $3.05 \text{ km}$.
We need to convert $3.05 \text{ km}$ to meters.  $1\text{ km} = 1{,}000 \text { m}$   So, $3.05\text{ km} = 3.05 \times {1{,}000}=3{,}050\text{ m}$.
Daniel walks $3{,}050 \text{ meters}$.
